summary.abstract: This chapter surveys astral knowledge in Islamicate societies from the 1st/7th through the 7th/13th centuries, treating astronomy and astrology as interrelated fields rather than separate disciplines. It examines the diverse classifications of the astral sciences proposed by philosophers including al-Kindī, Abū Maʿshar, al-Fārābī, and Ibn Sīnā, tracing debates over whether prognosticating sciences belong to mathematics or natural philosophy. The chapter also analyzes disputes about the structure of the universe, trepidation theory, and the philosophical foundations for planetary effects on the sublunar world. A concluding section addresses the nontrivial mathematical practices—including the projection of rays, house division, and horoscope computation—that demonstrate the scientific sophistication of medieval Islamic astrology.
